title: ðŸ“œ | Hello World!
description:
Welcome to this GreHack 2024 workshop on DOMLogger++! In this workshop, you should (hopefully) gain the skills to use DOMLogger++ effectively and configure it to meet your needs!

If you haven't installed the extension yet, download links (for Chromium and Firefox, sorry Safari users! :/) are available on the GitHub repository. You can also access them directly here:

1. Firefox: https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/domloggerpp/
2. Chromium: https://chromewebstore.google.com/detail/domlogger++/lkpfjhmpbmpflldmdpdoabimdbaclolp

Once you've installed it, the first thing to do is set up your target logging domains. This can be done through the DOMLogger++ icon (ðŸ”Ž) in your extension list by clicking on:

1. Add current domain for the current ETLD (e.g., a.mizu.re â†’ a.mizu.re)
2. Add current ETLD+1 for the current ETLD+1 (e.g., a.mizu.re â†’ mizu.re)
3. Or by entering a matching regex in the input form below

For now, simply click on "Add current domain" as we will be using DOMLogger++ on this website. Next, select a hooking configuration (leave it set to "DEFAULT" for now). Finally, you are ready to load all the sinks by navigating to your target website! After doing so, simply refreshing the page should complete this exercise!

conditions.description: Hook the .innerHTML attribute using the DEFAULT configuration.

title: â›µ | Navigating into logs
description:
Now that you've logged sinks with the DEFAULT configuration, you might want to view the results. To do this, open your devtools (F12) and click on the DOMLogger++ section at the top.

Once in the DOMLogger++ menu in devtools, you can do several things:

1. Filter sinks by category (more on this in the next exercise).
2. Search for specific data passed into the sink (highlighted in red in the table).
3. Use advanced search queries, e.g., "sink=a; href=b".
4. Manage the table (it's a basic DataTable, so you should quickly become familiar with it): sort, reorder, etc.
5. Search for data in the entire table (not just the data section).
6. Print the stack trace of the sink.
7. Reload the page where the sink was found and set a debugger breakpoint on it.
8. Go to GitHub, import logs, remove logs, export logs, and access settings.

More information is available in the README.md.


That's all for this exercise. You can press the button the "Solution" button to confirm you've read it!!

title: ðŸ“œ | Logging 101

conditions.description: Hook the setter of the .innerHTML attribute.
Hook the get method of the URLSearchParams class.
Hook the onerror event.
Hook the Function class.
Hook the custom global variable mizu.

title: ðŸ“œ | Config 101

conditions.description: Hook the .innerHTML attribute if it match /logger/.
If /domloggerpp/ match any sink, do not log it.
Hook the .outerHTML attribute if it not match /logger/.

conditions.expression: data.hook === 'attribute' && data.sink.includes('.outerHTML') && data.badge === true && data.notification === false
conditions.description: Trigger an alert without notification the .outerHTML sink is found.
Trigger an alert with a notification when /domlogger++/ match any sink.

title: ðŸ“¸ | Onmessage
description:
This time, it's more of a showcase rather than an exercise. The goal is to provide an example of basic hook/match/alert usage, which allows you to detect the onmessage event listener and receive a notification for interesting ones.

The only thing you need to do is retrieve the postmessages.json settings file available on the config folder of the GitHub repository, clear your logs and run it on this page. You should see several onmessage events found and receive 3 notifications about interesting ones :D

The idea behind this specific config is to pop up an alert if any dangerous function is used within the onmessage event itself. A good example of this is the usage of .indexOf or .match, which might lead to an origin bypass if used to verify the origin of the message.

To solve this exercise, you need to pop an alert() out of them.
Don't waste your time using another website, using postMessage from the console is enough.

title: ðŸ“œ | It doesn't works...
description:
One of the most commonly reported bugs to DOMLogger++ is related to sinks that it "doesn't find". This issue stems from the way browser extensions work.

Essentially, in order to work, DOMLogger++ injects a script at the very beginning of the DOM loading process. Because there's no way to instruct the browser to wait for a script to be loaded (or executed), the page will continue loading while the hooking configuration is being initialized.

As a result, there is a delay of about 20ms during which DOMLogger++ is effectively blind. While this delay is very small and doesn't usually impact its usage, it can cause DOMLogger++ to miss a sink that appears right at the beginning of the DOM.

To resolve this issue, I've suggested a fix using match-and-replace rules (<head> â†’ <head><script src="https://mizu.re/nocache.php"></script>) in Burp (this should also be possible with Caido), which is outlined in issue #10 (source available: here).

Since I can't set up the exercise auto-verifier this early on the page, you'll need to click on "solution" yourself once you've successfully logged it.

conditions.description: Hook the console.warn("DOMLogger++ [...]") call at the top of the document.

title: ðŸ“œ | Config 102

conditions.description: Hook the console.log function.
Use hideThis to remove this= in all function logging.
Sink must be logged only when "7.config102.js" is in the stack trace.

title: ðŸ“œ | Start logging when...

conditions.description: Hook the document.getElementsByClassName function.
Start hooking the document.selector sink only after the canary value reaches an .innerHTML sink.
Start hooking the document.getElementById sink only after the canary value reaches an .innerHTML sink.
Start hooking the document.getElementsByClassName sink only after the canary value reaches an .innerHTML sink.

title: ðŸ“¸ | Start logging when...
description:
It's showcase time! This time, you need to copy/paste the leverage-innerHTML.json configuration available in config folder of the GitHub repository. The only thing you need to do is clear your logs and put ?html=<required-match> in the search bar, then check your DOMLogger++ logs in the devtools.

You should see that logging begins only when the .innerHTML sink is triggered. The idea behind this configuration file is to log "almost" every interesting gadget that can be abused to bypass the HTML sanitizer.

Last thing: If you're wondering how document-based DOM Clobbering can be abused in a good way, you should take a look at Ishmeal's and Jackfromeast's DOM Clobbering reports on GitHub. For example, you can find a great case here (which I used for a challenge in the @HeroCTF â†’ ref): https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-4vvj-4cpr-p986

To solve this challenge, you need to find a way to trigger an alert().

title: ðŸš© | Bypass HTML Sanitizer 1
description:
Now that you are familiar with the leverage-innerHTML.json configuration, here is a small realistic challenge involving a gadget within the Materialize.js library.

To solve this challenge, you need to find a way to trigger an alert().

Small hintUsing the <option> tag at a specific place in your input might log an interesting gadget to look for ðŸ‘€

title: ðŸ“œ | Tracking execution flow 1
description:
The hookFunction configuration key is designed to infer with the sink arguments before they are consumed. To use it, you simply need to provide the string representation of the function to execute beforehand (ref). This function will receive 3 arguments:

1. thisArg: In the case of methods, this refers to the object the method affects.
2. args: The arguments the sink will receive.
3. target: The target string provided in the JSON configuration file.

For example: hookFunction: args += 'a'; return args (Always ensure the correct type for args before manipulating it â†’ If the hookFunction crashes, an error will be raised in the console).

One of the most powerful ways to use it is to detect patterns that require multiple sinks to occur in sequence. A good example is .innerText, which decodes HTML entities and can lead to XSS if its value is later assigned to .innerHTML. To hook into these patterns, you need to:

1. thisArg: In the case of methods, this refers to the object the method affects.
2. args: The arguments the sink will receive.
3. target: The target string provided in the JSON configuration file.

1. Use a canary value that will pass into the first sink (.innerText).
2. Update the canary's value with a new one using hookFunction (e.g., return args.replace('96923a0', '511b900').
3. Trigger an alert if the second sink (.innerHTML) matches the new canary value, indicating that it originated from an .innerText access.

The only things you need to take care of when doing this are:

1. Performance: Hooking heavily used functions might slow down your computer (with .innerText / .innerHTML, it should be fine).
2. DOS: Do not use a function you're currently hooking within the hookFunction, as this could lead to an unwanted DOS. Instead, use the domlogger.func object, which exposes all the functions you're currently hooking. For example, eval should be called as domlogger.func["eval"](...).

You need to use the ?html= parameter in addition of creating a config this time.

conditions.description: Hook get:Element.prototype.innerText and replace 01c346e with ded56df using hookFunction.
Hook get:Element.prototype.innerHTML only if it match ded56df.

title: ðŸš© | Bypass HTML Sanitizer 2
description:
For this challenge, the goal is to create a DOMLogger++ configuration that will automatically detect any .replace made to the output of DOMPurify.

Why is this important to check? The reason lies in how the content of <style> tags is processed. For example, replacing all instances of with an empty string could break the sanitization process. A good example is @kinugawamasato's TinyMCE bypass (CVE-2023-48219).

The only tip you need is this: even if DOMPurify is not defined globally (which would normally make it impossible to hook using a custom type), you can still hook into DOMParser.prototype.parseFromString, a method that is used internally to parse the HTML input string ;)

title: ðŸ“œ | Removing response headers
description:
Each configuration file has a removeHeaders (array) key, which, as the name suggests, needs to contain the response headers to remove. By default, each configuration file removes the Content-Security-Policy and X-Frame-Options headers.

For this exercise, you need to:
1. Select a configuration that removes the CSP / Frame policy response headers (the current one is probably a good choice).
2. Select Remove response headers in the DOMLogger++ popup option in the top right.
3. Refresh the page :)

title: ðŸ“¸ | Detect Client-Side Prototype Pollution
ðŸ“œ | Dynamic Regex Generation
ðŸ“¸ | Detect Client-Side Path Traversal
description:
Now that we know how to dynamically generate regex using the "exec:" directive, we are going to focus on how this can be powerfull in the context of Client-Side Path Traversal (CSPT) detection.

When you are looking for CSPT, you focus on 2 things:

1. The current location (path, query and hash) as this is the first sink of such attacks.
2. The path used while fetching a ressource with fetch, XMLHttpRequest...

Thanks to the "exec:" directive, we have all those information at the time the sink is being found. Thanks to this, it is possible, within the "exec:" directive to:

1. Get the current fetched path (depending on the sink).
2. Generate a word list out of that.
3. Check if one of those word is present in that path.
4. If so, raise a notification :D

Fortunately, I already made this job for you! Go on the GitHub and retrieve the cspt.json configuration file. If you want to look into the minified javascript source code, it is available here.

The only limitation out of it, is that it might generate a lot of false positive. Imagine a case where /api is present on both, the path of the page and the path wich is being fetched. In such a sitation DOMLogger++ is going to pop a notification as it match the prerequisis.

To ride this problem, I've created a banlist, which as to be allimented as long as you are testing your application. To make it easier to used, I've putted this list into the "globals" root key which as a reminder is available from window.domlogger.globals in javascript.

To solve this exercice, you need to:

1. Setup the cspt.json config file.
2. Go on /random.
3. See that DOMLogger++ detects it.
4. Pop an alter out of it :D

Oh, and by the way, this can also be used to detect document.cookie injections :p

title: â›µ | Limitations
description:
The last thing we need to cover is the limitations of DOMLogger++ (as of the time of writing this workshop). If we don't consider the race condition during initialization, which we covered in "It doesn't work...", here's what's not possible for now:

1. If you hook too many things at once, your computer might start to get slow. In the worst cases, your browser might crash.
2. There are some very specific methods you can't hook, such as: Reflect.apply, this.nodeName.toLowerCase, etc.
3. The "goto" button doesn't work if the sink has been found within an iframe.
4. document.write can't be hooked (see #30).
5. I don't think it would be easy to use DOMLogger++ on headless browsers (I'll be honest, I haven't tried it).
6. WebSockets don't work in the webhook, and no backend server is available to properly use it.

That's mostly all (for the main known issues)!

title: â›µ | Everything comes to an end...
description:
At the time of writing this workshop, we should have finished covering everything that needs to be covered related to DOMLogger++! I hope you enjoyed the workshop and that the tool will help you in your future client-side tests :D

Oh, and! As I mentioned at the very beginning (for those attending in person), I tried to design this extension in a way that nobody will feel limited while using it. Thus, everything in the UI can be configured ðŸ‘€

If you go into the settings, you should see:

1. PwnFox (Firefox only): Allows you to enable DOMLogger++ only in the PwnFox container.
2. Webhook (HTTP only for now): Allows you to receive logs on a remote HTTP server.
3. Devtools: Allows you to enable or disable the Devtools tab.
4. Customize: Allows you to update the table in Devtools (add, remove, swap columns).
5. Colors: Allows you to update the colors of the whole extension ;D

Now that you know everything, if you're interested in helping the project grow, feel free to create issues or pull requests (PRs) if you find any bugs or interesting ways to improve the tool :D

Have a good day!
Mizu.
